feature.name: daily wage calculator
feature.description: The daily wage calculator is a payroll feature that automatically computes the daily pay rate for employees taking unpaid leave by dividing their total salary (basic + allowance) by the number of actual working days in the month. It accounts for different leave policies (calendar days or working days) and automatically deducts public holidays from the working day count to ensure accurate salary deductions. Upon approval of an unpaid leave request, the system generates an automatic pay deduction that is reflected on the payroll table. This feature ensures consistent and compliant salary calculations across the organization's leave management process.

source_articles_index.title: How is daily pay calculated
source_articles_index.article_summary: This article explains how daily pay is calculated for unpaid leave deductions. It provides the formula (Daily Pay = Salary Amount / Actual Working Days), describes how to account for different leave policies (calendar vs. working days), and explains the process of deducting public holidays from working days. It also documents that automatic pay deductions are created and reflected on the payroll table upon approval of unpaid leave requests.

source_articles_index.title: Introduction to daily wage calculator
source_articles_index.article_summary: Introductory article explaining the Daily Wage Calculator feature, its purpose in replacing limited wage calculation options, and its three main calculation bases (calendar days, working days, custom days). Describes how the feature impacts salary proration, leave encashment, and unpaid leave deductions, and provides navigation path to access the tool (Settings → Payroll → Daily Wage Calculation).

source_articles_index.title: Salary Proration
source_articles_index.article_summary: Explains how Super admins can update salary proration settings in the Daily Wage Calculator (DWC) by selecting calculation bases (custom days, calendar days, or working days). Covers navigation path (Settings > Payroll > Daily wage calculation), the impact on active payroll transactions, and the requirement to reject existing prorated salary transactions when payroll month is open before saving new proration settings.

job_to_be_done.statement: Calculate and deduct daily pay for employees taking unpaid leave by determining the appropriate salary reduction based on the number of working or calendar days, accounting for public holidays and leave policy type.

Provide a flexible and customizable method for calculating daily wages to determine salary proration, leave encashment, and unpaid leave deduction amounts with greater control over calculation bases and salary components.

Adjust and calculate an employee's salary proportionally based on the actual days worked, affecting their first salary and end-of-service settlement by selecting appropriate calculation bases (custom days, calendar days, or working days).

procedures.procedure_name: Calculate Daily Pay for Unpaid Leave Deduction
procedures.when_to_use: When an unpaid leave request is approved and a salary deduction needs to be generated for the payroll system.
steps: Receive and approve the unpaid leave request
Determine the applicable leave policy type (calendar days or working days)
Identify the total number of days in the policy (e.g., 30 calendar days or 22 working days)
Identify all public holidays falling within the month of calculation
Subtract public holidays from the total working days to obtain actual working days
Retrieve the employee's total salary amount (Basic + Allowance)
Apply the formula: Daily Pay = Salary Amount / Actual Working Days
System automatically creates the pay deduction and reflects it on the payroll table

procedures.when_to_use: When setting up or updating daily wage calculation methodology for payroll processing.
steps: Navigate to Settings from the main menu
Select Payroll from the settings options
Select the desired calculation base: calendar days, working days, or custom days
Choose which salary components to include in the calculation
Apply the configuration to activate the daily wage calculation method

procedures.when_to_use: When configuring or modifying how employee salaries are prorated based on days worked
steps: Navigate to Settings > Payroll > Daily wage calculation
Select calculation basis: custom days, calendar days, or working days
Make necessary changes with required calculation bases
If payroll month is open and prorated salary transactions exist, reject existing transactions before saving new proration settings

rules_limitations_constraints.rule: Daily pay is calculated by dividing total salary (Basic + Allowance) by the number of actual working days in the month, not calendar days unless the leave policy explicitly uses calendar days. ; Leave policy can follow either calendar days (e.g., 30 days) or working days (e.g., 22 working days) framework; the policy type determines which base number is used in the calculation. ; Public holidays falling within the calculation month must be deducted from the working days count to arrive at actual working days for the daily pay calculation. ; Pay deduction is automatically created and reflected on the payroll table only upon approval of the unpaid leave request; no manual intervention is required.

Calendar days calculation uses the actual number of days in each month (e.g., 31 days in January, 28 days in February). ; Working days calculation excludes weekends and public holidays as defined in the company's public holiday calendar. ; Custom days calculation allows payroll managers to set a fixed number of days per month according to company policies; most UAE and KSA companies set this to 30 days to comply with local labor law. ; Only Superadmin, Payroll table managers, or transaction processors can select and modify the calculation base.

Changes to salary proration settings will affect all active (unpaid) amounts in the payroll table immediately upon saving. ; When payroll month is open and prorated salary transactions are submitted for one or multiple employees, the Super admin must reject the transactions with prorated salaries before saving new proration changes.

edge_cases_warnings.edge_case_or_warning: When public holidays occur during the calculation month, they must be explicitly subtracted from the working days total. For example, if 2 days are public holidays and the policy is 22 working days, the daily pay calculation uses 20 days instead of 22 days. ; Organizations using calendar days leave policy (e.g., 30 days) will calculate daily pay differently than those using working days policy (e.g., 22 days); ensure the correct policy type is applied.

Monthly variation in calendar days (ranging from 28 to 31 days) will directly impact calculated daily wage rates when using calendar days as the calculation base. ; Different calculation methods (calendar days vs. working days vs. custom days) will produce different daily wage rates and therefore different final amounts for salary proration, leave encashment, and unpaid leave deductions.

When payroll month is open with existing prorated salary transactions, Super admin must manually reject and resave transactions to apply new proration settings; failure to do so may result in inconsistent salary calculations.

Daily Wage Calculator directly impacts salary proration, leave encashment, and unpaid leave deduction calculations within the payroll system. ; When working days calculation base is selected, the feature depends on the company's public holiday calendar to exclude public holidays from the calculation.
Daily Wage Calculator interacts with the Payroll system and directly affects active payroll table transactions, particularly impacting first salary calculations and end-of-service settlements.
